awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:NSF: Amplification of drought effects on vegetation by anthropogenic warming
awd_abstract_narration:
Droughts are among the world’s costliest natural disasters, causing severe damage to both social and ecological systems. Human-caused warming increases the “dryness” of the atmosphere and, all other things being equal, increases evaporation rates from plant and soil surfaces, which in turn increases the loss of soil moisture and worsens naturally occurring precipitation deficits. Drought reduces the photosynthesis and productivity of plants, including in both natural and agricultural ecosystems, but the extent to which human-caused ecological change has amplified the effects of drought on plant productivity still remains unclear. This EPSCoR RII Track-4:NSF Fellowship will combine state-of-the-art satellite and ground-based plant observations with observed and modeled climate data to examine how much the past century of climate change has worsened drought effects on plants, focusing specifically on the relative contributions of natural- vs. human-caused effects during two recent severe droughts: the 2012-2015 California drought and the 2012 Midwest drought. The project will improve our understanding of the extent to which the effects of drought on Earth’s ecosystems are amplified by climate change, and it will also improve educational outcomes through training of a postdoctoral researcher and development of new climate change-related laboratory exercises for courses at the University of Iowa.

Droughts are among the world’s costliest natural disasters, causing severe damage to both social and ecological systems. Anthropogenic warming exacerbates natural precipitation deficits through heat-induced increases in evaporative demand, which further dries soils and stresses vegetation. Anthropogenic increases in the frequency and severity of droughts likely exert large, but still poorly constrained, impacts on ecosystem function, including photosynthesis and growth of plants (“primary production”). While drought clearly reduces vegetation health and primary production, the relative contributions of natural variability and anthropogenic forcing remain unknown. Using the severe 2012-2015 California and 2012 Midwest droughts as case studies, this project will quantify the proportion of drought-induced primary production loss that was directly attributable to anthropogenic climate change, including attribution to specific climatic drivers (temperature, vapor pressure deficit, soil moisture, and solar radiation). The primary hypothesis of this proposal is that anthropogenic contributions to drought-induced loss of primary production were even greater than anthropogenic contributions to loss of soil moisture due to the direct negative effects of higher temperatures and evaporative demand on stomatal conductance and photosynthesis. This hypothesis will be tested using state-of-the-art remote sensing techniques (e.g., solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence) and climate change attribution methods. The ultimate goal of this research is to develop an empirical “global change ecology” attribution framework that will be portable to other ecological systems and other impacts of climate change, including follow-up work focused on the effects of climate change on nationwide changes in primary production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Matthew Dannenberg and the postdoctoral research associate supported by the project (Dr. Miriam Johnston) completed a six-month fellowship, supported by the NSF EPSCoR RII Track-4 program, at UCLA from June to November 2023. During the project period, Dannenberg and Johnston developed a global change ecology attribution framework and used that framework to examine how anthropogenic climate change affects carbon and water cycling in the United States (U.S.) during extreme events. They specifically examined changes in ecosystem carbon uptake during extreme droughts in the western U.S. and changes in Missouri River streamflow in the midwestern U.S. They found that anthropogenic climate change, especially increases in the evaporative demand of the atmosphere, has greatly exacerbated the negative effects of naturally occurring drought on vegetation carbon uptake in the western U.S., causing nearly half of the reduction in primary production during the extreme 21st century droughts in the region. They also found that most of the 20th to 21st century increase in streamflow in the Missouri River basin was due to a combination of “natural” climate variability, land-use change, and enhanced CO2 concentrations, whereas anthropogenic climate change on its own likely would have led to decreases, rather than increases, in streamflow due to increased evaporative demand of the atmosphere. As of May 2024, the project has resulted in two published peer-reviewed papers, with several more either under review or in preparation. During the fellowship period, Dannenberg and Johnston also participated in and presented at multiple workshops and conferences, including the Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting (Johnston only) and the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union (both Dannenberg and Johnston).

 

As stated in the EPSCoR RII Track-4 goals, the fellowship “will positively impact and potentially transform the PI’s individual career trajectory” by allowing him to expand his research in a new and exciting direction. The fellowship supported development of an empirical “global change ecology” attribution framework that will enhance the PI’s research portfolio and strengthen his competitiveness for future proposals focused on ecosystem responses to climate change. The fellowship also greatly expanded the PI’s collaborative network, resulting in participation in papers and grant proposals that he likely would not otherwise have been invited to participate in. The fellowship also supported development of research and professional networks for Dr. Johnston, who joined the PI at UCLA during the fellowship period. This experience enhanced and expanded her research and provided opportunities for collaboration at the host institution. As a direct result of the fellowship, Dr. Johnston also received her next postdoctoral position. The project also improved teaching and educational experiences and research infrastructure in the PI’s home jurisdiction. During the project period (immediately preceding the fellowship period at UCLA), Dannenberg developed and taught a new upper-division Climate Change class at the University of Iowa for the first time, which will likely be taught regularly as part of his course rotation. The next iteration of the class will also include insights gathered during the fellowship period, including an expansion of the lab activities to more explicitly separate the effects of natural variability from anthropogenic forcing on climate change in Iowa. As a result of ideas generated during the fellowship period, the PI also developed and submitted a successful instrumentation proposal to obtain plant growth chambers for use in global change experiments and in student lab exercises and independent projects in ecology, sustainability, and environmental science courses at University of Iowa.
